s.text: In this way Gross hopes to make back his costs and then some.
Exchanging stuff for eyeballs makes sense as long as the cost of providing the stuff is less than the value of the eyeballs to advertisers.

To get a sense of how valuable targeting is to advertisers, the New York Times-- which makes you give demographic information in order to register for the site--charges four cents for a banner ad that's shown to everyone and six cents for one that is targeted.
Add $100 a year for the Internet connection and the service contract and assume the computer has a usable life of two years.
The Web is full of sites that give away valuable stuff free in the hope of making it back in advertising.
A banner at the top of a Web page just isn't the same as a luxurious two-page color spread.
